results.title: ‘Everything Changed Overnight’: Afghan Reporters Face an Intolerant Regime
results.abstract: The Taliban promised to respect press freedoms, but the new government has already showed signs of repression, and has even physically assaulted Afghan journalists.

results.title: ‘It’s a Godsend’: 9-Cent Taxi Rides in Rural South Korea
results.abstract: One county’s plan to help older, carless citizens stuck in remote villages proved wildly popular and has been copied across South Korea, revolutionizing public transportation in the countryside.

results.title: 20 Years On, the War on Terror Grinds Along, With No End in Sight
results.abstract: The failures in Iraq and Afghanistan obscure what experts say is the striking success of a multilateral effort that extends to as many as 85 countries.

results.title: Times Investigation: In U.S. Drone Strike, Evidence Suggests No ISIS Bomb

results.title: The ‘Plagiarism Hunter’ Terrorizing the German-Speaking World
results.abstract: Stefan Weber has ended careers, forced politicians from office, hounded scores of others and even created a thriving business in his quest to end literary theft.

multimedia.caption: Stefan Weber, an Austrian communications professor and self-appointed plagiarist hunter, at Mooncity, a museum in Salzburg. His latest prominent target is Annalena Baerbock, the German candidate for chancellor from the Green Party.

results.title: At Pro-Taliban Protest, a Symbol of America’s Lost Influence: Hundreds Dressed in Burqas
results.abstract: Several hundred women wore the head-to-toe garments at a pro-Taliban demonstration on Sept. 11. The march was a reminder of how after years of war, Afghanistan’s women are again at the mercy of the militants.

results.title: Abimael Guzmán, Leader of Guerrilla Group That Terrorized Peru, Dies at 86
results.abstract: Mr. Guzmán’s Maoist movement, Shining Path, killed tens of thousands in the 1980s and ’90s. He sought to bring the world to a “higher stage of Marxism.”

results.title: Unearthed at a British Golf Course: A Log Coffin From the Bronze Age

results.title: ‘We Truly Have Lost Everything’: A Journey Out of Kabul the Day It Fell
results.abstract: Nadima Sahar, a government official, was determined to stay. But then she learned the palace staff, and maybe even the president, had already fled.

multimedia.caption: For Nadima Sahar and thousands of others, fleeing Afghanistan meant abandoning the only home they knew.

results.title: More Asia-Pacific countries warily ease their tough anti-Covid rules.
results.byline: By John Yoon and Jin Yu Young

multimedia.caption: Singapore opened its borders to more countries and loosened quarantine rules for some inbound travelers on Friday. Cases have risen recently, but the number of severe cases has leveled off.

results.title: 5 Takeaways From Canada’s Official Election Debates
results.abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who called the snap election two years ahead of schedule, was repeatedly attacked by the other four candidates.

results.title: Biden Speaks With Xi Amid Low Point in U.S.-China Relations
results.abstract: The call was only the second time the leaders had spoken since President Biden’s inauguration. The lack of communication was a measure of the rising tensions between the two countries.
results.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and David E. Sanger

multimedia.caption: The call between President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China on Thursday reflected the sense of urgency in the White House to compete with Beijing and establish policymaking expectations.
multimedia.copyright: Al Drago for The New York Times

results.title: First Flight From Kabul Is Hailed as Positive Step Amid Troubling Signs
results.abstract: A passenger jet’s departure on Thursday was the first foreign flight out of Afghanistan since the U.S. evacuation ended. But thousands who want to leave remain stuck.
results.byline: By Victor J. Blue, Sami Sahak, Lara Jakes and Eric Nagourney

multimedia.caption: Passengers boarding a Qatar Airways plane in Kabul on Thursday. Scores of Americans, Canadians and Britons were on the flight.

results.title: Russia and Belarus Inch Closer to a Full-Blown Merger
results.abstract: In their sixth meeting in less than a year, the countries’ presidents agreed to deepen economic ties, leaving tougher political questions for later.

multimedia.caption: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Thursday to discuss further integration of their countries.
multimedia.copyright: Pool photo by Mikhail Voskresenskiy
